Understanding web mapping

A map on the Internet shouldn’t be just a picture. There is potential for interaction, animation, 3D, and more! Even better, the Internet can allowus to share our maps and spatial data more effectively than ever.

How does a map work on the web?

Anatomy of a web map Zooming Tiling Interaction Sharing

Web map frameworks

Leaflet.js

Leaflet.js is a light-weight open-source JavaScript library. This is the ‘easiest’ framework to use for developing web maps.

Leaflet is a modern open-source JavaScript library for mobile-friendly interactive maps. It is developed by Vladimir Agafonkin with a team of dedicated contributors. Weighing just about 33 KB of JS, it has all the features most developers ever need for online maps.


OpenLayers 3

OpenLayers is an open-source JavaScript library.


Here are OpenLayers 3 examples

D3.js

D3 is an excellent tool for visualizing spatial data, but flexes its muscles with non-spatial data.

Spatial Data


Non-spatial data

Force-Directed Graph explained here


Tile Map Service (TMS)

Here’s a list of tile map service (TMS) providers. Nearly all TMS providers are free for personal use.

Mapbox Suite is ideal for creating custom basemaps.

A basemap is what your spatial data layers are set on top of.

Satellite imagery is the most commonly know type of TMS. Mapbox Suite uses vector data to create basemaps. Frameworks such as Leaflet.js allow you to overlay spatial data on top of TMS/basemaps.


Leaflet.js basic tutorials

Read below for basic Leaflet.js tutorials. Most of the code can be ‘easily’ figured out by reading the parameters already set. Basic knowledge of HTML and CSS are a plus, and basics of JavaScript will help you develop interactive maps.

View the Leaflet.js API here

qgis2leaf

A simple user-friendly method of creating a basic Leaflet with a layer through QGIS. See the GitHub repository here.

  1. Open QGIS and install qgis2leaf plugin:
    • Menu Bar > Plugins > Manage and Install PLugins > Search ‘qgis2leaf’
  2. Add vector layer.
    • NOTE: vector data is stored as points (with lines connecting lines, polylines, and polygons). The output of a 90MB shapefile to GeoJSON is nearly 300MB (this will vary, however). Understanding your data beforehand will help you in the long run. See Data Wrangling
